A series of hybrid catalysts with different catalytic bed dispositions (layer bed and simple random mixture) of Cu- 
ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 have been adopted and evaluated in syngas conversion into light C2-C4 hydrocarbons. 
An effect of the proximity between the two solids on the CO hydrogenation activity was demonstrated. A sphere 
contact quantification model was developed to estimate the concentration of contact between them for any 
simple random mixture. Comparing the evolution of gain of CO conversion (or hydrocarbon yield) with the 
theoretical results, it was shown that the density of contact was identified as the key factor for the catalytic 
performances (contact-activity relationship). Finally, the knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by 
FEG-SEM, allowed proposing the NH3-TPD as method characterizing the concentration of contact.   
1.Introduction 
Light (C2-C4) hydrocarbons are important chemical building blocks 
for a variety of useful derivatives in the petrochemical and chemical 
industries [1,2] . They are presently produced worldwide in huge 
amounts mostly by steam cracking of naphta which is highly 
energy-consuming process. C2-C4 hydrocarbons synthesis from syngas 
(a mixture of CO and H2) is attractive since renewable carbon resources 
(biomass, wastes, CO2) are expected to gradually replace fossil fuels [3]. 
Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis is the traditional process of converting 
syngas to hydrocarbons [4]. However, the FT process is limited by the 
Anderson�Schultz�Flory (ASF) distribution and contain a small yield of 
C2-C4 hydrocarbons [5,6] . 
A two-step process including methanol synthesis (Reaction 1) fol-
lowed by methanol-to-olefins (MTO, Reaction 2) process is commer -
cially available to produce light hydrocarbons but development of a 
more energetically and costly-efficient direct process is needed [7].

The advantage of the single-step process is the achievement of both reactions (Reactions 1 and 2) in one reactor in order to simplify the 
process route and equipment [4]. This process is possible using a 
so-called hybrid or bifunctional catalyst. The bifunctional catalyst cor-
responds to a physical mixture of methanol synthesis catalyst (Cu-Z -
nO-Al 2O3) and zeotype (SAPO-34), can lead to the formation of light 
hydrocarbons from syngas via methanol as reactional intermediate [4,8, 
9]. The main advantage of the single-step process is the elimination of 
the restriction of methanol synthesis by the thermodynamic equilibrium 
shift (drain-off mechanism) [10]. It can be assumed therefore that the 
proximity between methanol synthesis catalyst and SAPO-34 (where the 
methanol is converted) plays a significant role in the catalytic perfor -
mances (high. CO conversion) and in the hydrocarbon selectivity [9]. 
In the present work, we investigated the activity of hybrid catalyst 
for the CO hydrogenation into hydrocarbons (HC) as a function con-
centration of contact between methanol synthesis catalyst (M1) and 
SAPO-34 (M2). In order to evaluate the effect of the proximity between 
M1 and M2, different catalytic bed dispositions (layer bed, denoted LB, 
and simple random mixture, denoted SRM) of both components have 
been adopted. Using a similar methodology as previously described [11, 
12], we built contact –reactivity relationship on the basis of catalytic 
observations. The results led us to formulate hypotheses concerning the 
morphology of the contacts, as well as the development of a

2.Materials and methods 
2.1. Materials 
2.1.1. Methanol synthesis catalyst 
A commercially available methanol synthesis copper-based catalyst 
(M1) was used. This is a material developed by Johnson Matthey and 
sold by Alfa Aesar (a Johnson Matthey company) in the form of 
5.4mm×3.6mm pellets. These pellets were crushed and sized to 
160�100 µm (in this form, the apparent density of the M1 (denoted 
ρM1) material is equal to 1.23 gcm-3 and the radius of the M1 material is 
rM1 =65.0 µm). 
2.1.2. SAPO-34 
A SAPO-34 zeolite (M2) in the form of fine powder was purchased 
from ACS Material. It was pelletized, crushed and sized to 160�100 µm 
(in this form, the apparent density of the M2 (denoted ρM2) material is 
equal to 0.94 gcm-3 and the radius of the M2 material is rM2 =65.0 µm). 
2.1.3. Hybrid catalysts 
2.1.3.1. Layer bed arrangements. The layer bed arrangements (denoted 
xLB(y), where x and y represent the number of layers and the number of 
contacts, in terms of contact section between M1 and M2, respectively) 
are presented in the Table S1. The same amount of M1 (160�100 µm) 
and M2 (160�100 µm) reference materials was used for each of LB arrangement. The differences between the LB arrangements are the 
number of alternating layers between M1 and M2, resulting a change in 
the number of contacts (see Table S1). 
2.1.3.2. Simple random mixture arrangements. The simple random 
mixture arrangements (denoted SRM(x), where x represents the M2 
proportion) were prepared by simple mixing M1 (160�100 µm) and M2 
(160�100 µm) reference materials with different weight ratios. The 
characteristics of SRM arrangements are presented in the Table S2.

3.2. Catalytic performances 
3.2.1. M1+M2 arrangements 
3.2.1.1. Catalytic performances with layered bed (LB) arrangements. The 
impact of the contact concentration between M1 and M2 is investigated 
using the different layered bed arrangements present in the Table S1. 
The performance of M1 and different catalytic layered bed arrangements 
at 15h of reaction is shown in Fig. 3 (the evolution of the CO conversion 
and the product selectivities versus the time on stream is presented in 
Fig. S4). The M1 catalyzed the conversion of syngas to CH4, CO2 and 
hydrocarbons (denoted HC, mostly C2H6) with selectivities of approxi -
mately 45%, 40% and 10%, respectively. The CO conversion (denoted 
XCO) is approximately 7% (with WHSV=10L.h-1.g-1, see Fig. 3a); and methanol (denoted MeOH) and dimethylether (denoted DME) traces are 
observed (Fig. 3b). These results clearly indicate that, under our 
experimental conditions, M1 favors the methanation and Water Gas 
Shift (WGS) reactions at the expense of methanol synthesis reaction, 
which is also in agreement with the thermodynamic equilibrium data 
presented in Table S5. No activity is observed for M2 alone (not pre-
sented here). When the M2 catalyst is associated with the M1 catalyst, 
without contact (2LB(0) arrangement, where M1 and M2 are separated 
from each other by a 1cm thick layer of SiC), the CO conversion (Fig. 3a) 
and the CH4 and CO2 selectivities (Fig. 3b) are not changed compared to 
the test with the M1 catalyst alone. However, the disappearance of 
MeOH and DME is observed in favor of hydrocarbons. When the both 
catalysts are in contact (2LB(1), 4LB(3), 6LB(5), 8LB(7) and 10LB(9) 
arrangements), an increase in CO conversion (Fig. 3a) and HC selectivity 
(mostly C3H8) and a decrease in CH4 selectivity are observed (Fig. 3b, 
the CO2 selectivity is constant for all the catalytic tests). This phenom -
enon is amplified with the increase in the number of contacts between 
M1 and M2 layers. The formation of hydrocarbons is explained by the 
transformation of methanol intermediate formed over M1 into hydro -
carbons over M2 acid sites, thus inhibiting the CO methanation and/or 
the hydrogenation of MeOH into CH4 over M1[13]. The intimacy be-
tween both materials leads to a strong increase in the proportion of 
paraffins relative to olefins (see the P/O ratio in Fig. 3b), indicating the 
hydrogenation of the olefins. Hydrogen spillover (from M1 to M2) 
and/or olefins spillover (from M2 to M1) and/or the hydrogenation of 
olefins by crossing through a layer of M1 would probably explain this 
[14,15] .

3.2.1.2. Catalytic performances with simple random mixture (SRM) 
arrangements. In order to improve the CO conversion, different simple 
random mixtures of M1 and M2 were made. Different compositions of 
these SRM arrangements were used to vary the contact concentration

The impact of the composition of the SRM arrangement at 15h of

reduction) as well as in mixtures of different compositions, according 
with the methodology used in our previous study to determine the 
concentration of number of contacts between two materials [12]. With 
the statistical and geometric approach of the Dodds model [16,17] , it is 
possible to easily describe the texture of a 3D polydisperse random 
mixture. The Dodds model assumes that each particle constituting the 
polydisperse mixture is in contact with all its neighbors. This basic hy-
pothesis allows to divide the space into tetrahedral subunits ijkl (i, j, k 
and l representing the indices of the species constituting the four vertices 
of a tetrahedron), containing a part of vacuum and each vertex being the 
center of a given particle. A binary random mixture (composed of 2 
families of type 1 and 2 particles, representing M1 and M2, respectively 
for this study) has 5 types of tetrahedral subunits (1111, 1112, 1122, 
1222, and 2222, Fig. 5b). These different tetrahedral subunits are 
geometrically fully characterized with the angles a, b and c at the 
summit i, the spherical angles α, β and γ and the area AT of the spherical 
triangle (ABC) [18]. The geometry of such a tetrahedral subunit is 
completely described by the radii of the four spheres forming it (ri, rj, rk 
et rj). By knowing the particles radii and their distributions in number, it 
is possible to determine coordination numbers, porosity, and distribu -
tion of the different contact types in the polydisperse mixture. In the 
spirit of the Dodds model, model calculations were performed. A 
mathematical model was developed in order to determine the concen -
tration of number of contacts between M1–M1, M2–M2, and M1–M2 
(denoted [NC11], [NC22], and [NC12] and expressed in number of 
contacts per gram of catalyst) for any composition of the SRM catalyst 
(see Fig. 5c, all the details of the proposed model are presented in the 
supporting information in the section “Description of the contact 
model ”). 
In order to have a representative view of the impact of the M1-M2 contacts in the XCOgain , we compared the evolution of the normalized 
concentration of number of contacts between M1–M2 with the 
normalized XCOgain as a function of the M2 proportion in the catalyst 
(Fig. 5d). It clearly appears that the obtained volcano curve for the 
concentration of number of contacts between M1 and M2 with a 
maximum at 50% M2 is identical to the one obtained for the normalized 
XCOgain . This result validates the contact –reactivity relationship 
hypothesis. 
3.4. Reduced SRM arrangement structure and morphology 
We observed that the CO conversion is dramatically affected by the 
SRM catalyst composition, and therefore by the amount of M1-M2 
contacts present in the hybrid materials. We investigated the structure 
and textural parameters for the best CO conversion catalyst (SRM(0.50)) 
to understand the nature of M1-M2 contacts. The XRD diffractogram at 
the fresh plotted in Fig. S6a is a linear combination of the M1 and M2 
ones. After reduction, it corresponds to a combination of the diffracto -
gram of reduced M1 and to the one of SAPO-34 for which the peaks are 
slightly shifted to the low angles (Fig. S6b). This shift could be due to 
cationic exchange within the zeotype. [19,20] The morphology of the 
reduced SRM(0.50) catalyst obtained by FEG-SEM measurements is 
presented in Fig. 6 (see also Fig. S7 in supporting Information for the 
complete EDX mapping analysis). The reduced catalyst behaves like a 
dense packing of randomly distributed binary grains with grain sizes 
similar to those of the fresh hybrid catalyst (Fig. 6a), which agrees with 
the starting point of our theoretical model (Fig. 5a). In order to differ -
entiate the nature of each catalyst grain, a mapping of the main char-
acteristic elements of M1 and M2 (Cu (in red) and P (in yellow), 
respectively) was carried out (Fig. 6b). It can be seen that, after the 
reduction, this granular mixture includes not only conventional contacts 
between the grains of M1 and M2 (as one might expect), but also a

3.5. Characterization of the M1-M2 contacts 
The quantity of interphases between M1 and M2 can be determined, 
indirectly, using the properties of a Cu exchanged SAPO-34 synthesis 
method, generally used for the selective catalytic reduction with 
ammonia (NH 3-SCR) [19]. This method, named solid-state ion-exchange 
(SSIE), consists in mixing copper oxide with SAPO-34 and heating it at low temperature (T<250◦C) under an atmosphere of NH3, which leads 
to the diffusion of metal ions in the zeolite [19]. The mobility of Cu is 
proposed to be related to the formation of complexes [Cu(I)(NH 3)x]+
(x≥2). Indeed, these linear complexes have a diameter similar to that of 
an NH3 molecule, thus allowing these species to easily penetrate into the 
porous system of the zeolite and thus to improve the Cu exchange. One 
can thus easily imagine that if one carries out this method with our 
materials (LB and SRM arrangements), the mobility of Cu should in-
crease with the concentration of contact between M1 and M2. The use of 
NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH 3-TPD) on our materials 
allows not only to perform the SSIE process during the NH3 adsorption 
step, but also to indirectly quantify the amount of Cu exchanged in M2 
(and therefore a representation of M1-M2 contact concentration).

some cations to the framework [28,29] ) and a high temperature (HT) 
peak (>400◦C, attributed to NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites i.e. 
formation of NH4+[20–24]). NH3-TPD of reduced SRM(0.50) followed 
by DRIFT spectroscopy (Fig. S8) confirmed the presence of Lewis acid 
sites (bands at 3385 –3335, 3275, 1622, 1274 and 1219 cm-1) and 
Brønsted acid sites (3270, 1490 –1450 cm-1) as well as NH3 adsorbed on 
Cu+sites on SAPO-34 (3184 cm-1). A detailed attribution is provided in 
the supporting information .

different masses of M1 and M2 alone. From these new profiles, it was

4.Conclusion 
In order to evaluate the effect of the proximity between Cu-ZnO- 
Al2O3 and SAPO-34 in the conversion of CO into hydrocarbons, different 
catalytic bed dispositions (LB and SRM) of both components have been 
adopted. When the SAPO-34 catalyst was associated with the Cu-ZnO- 
Al2O3 catalyst (LB arrangement), without contact, CO conversion has 
not changed compared to the test with the M1 catalyst alone. However, 
the disappearance of methanol and DME was observed in favor of hy-
drocarbons (with a significant selectivity toward CH4 and CO2). When 
both catalysts were in contact (LB arrangement), an increase of CO 
conversion and HC selectivity and a decrease of CH4 selectivity were 
observed. This phenomenon is amplified with the increase of the contact 
concentration. In order to improve the CO conversion, different SRM of 
Cu-ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 were made. The impact of the composition 
of the SRM hybrid catalyst was investigated and shown a volcano-like 
profile for CO conversion as a function of M2 content in the catalyst. 
To elucidate the effect of composition on CO conversion a mathematical 
model for Cu-ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 contact quantification, based on a 
geometrical and statistical approach allowing the textural description of 
a random polydisperse medium, was developed. The experimental re-
sults were compared with theoretical calculations. A direct correlation 
was found between theory and experiment. The density of contact be-
tween Cu-ZnO-Al 2O3 and SAPO-34 was identified as the key factor for 
the catalytic performances (contact-activity relationships). Finally, the 
knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by FEG-SEM, 
allowed proposing the NH3-TPD as the concentration of contact char-
acterization method.

The rising concerns about global warming and imbalance in the carbon cycle urge rapid development of
efﬁcient CO 2conversion processes. We report an exceptionally productive process for the synthesis of
methanol via continuous catalytic hydrogenation of CO 2under high-pressure conditions (up to
360 bar) over co-precipitated Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalysts. Outstanding one-pass CO 2conversion (>95%) and
methanol selectivity (>98%) were achieved under an optimized range of reaction conditions. At a very
high GHSV of 182,000 h/C01over a commercial methanol synthesis catalyst, the process delivers
7:7gMeOH g/C01
cath/C01, which is by far the highest yield value reported to date, at the expense of lowered
CO2conversion (65.8%) and methanol selectivity (77.3%). Using a mixed bed consisting of the Cu/ZnO/
Al2O3and H-ZSM-5 catalysts, one-step conversion of CO 2into dimethyl ether with remarkable selectivity
(89%) was attained at the equivalent or higher CO 2conversion level. Furthermore, we demonstrate that
the efﬂuent stream of methanol, rich in H 2and water, from the methanol synthesis reactor can be directly
fed to a reactor containing the H-ZSM-5 catalyst for selective production of alkane (85%) or alkene (42%),
depending on the operating pressure of the secondary reactor.

1. Introduction
The global warming, mainly sourced from the human induced
emission of CO 2, is one of the major environmental threats we
are facing in the 21st century. In the past few decades, there has
been growing scientiﬁc consensus to devise the strategy for CO 2
capture, ﬁxation, and recycling technologies to level off the atmo-spheric CO
2concentration. Nature has its own CO 2ﬁxation process
which is extraordinarily selective in converting CO 2into organic
compounds. However, natural chemical transformation of CO 2is
not simply fast enough to cope with the increasing CO 2emission
rate of the industrialized world. Chemical transformation of CO 2
is not only about mitigating the global warming; rather it is aboutrecycling of the carbon, irreversibly relocated in the form of CO
2
from the ground by burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and natu-
ral gas. In the light of the ﬁnite availability of fossil fuels, the pro-
duction of commercially valuable chemicals and fuels from CO 2is a
promising strategy to simultaneously tackle the two major prob-
lems of the century, namely the global warming and fossil fuel
depletion, for sustainable development. Among others, heteroge-
neous catalytic hydrogenation of CO 2bears a strong potential totreat large amount of CO 2in a short time, rendering it an important
mean for CO 2conversion.
Methanol (MeOH) can be synthesized from CO 2hydrogenation
and is one of the most celebrated and widely suggested alterna-
tives for chemical energy carrier [1,2] . It is an excellent fuel and
a key starting material of the important industrial reactions. The
use of methanol in fuel cells directly or indirectly as the source
of hydrogen by a reforming reaction is well documented. Actively
investigated hydrogen production by photocatalytic or electrocat-
alytic water splitting powered by renewable (e.g. solar and wind)
energies can be regarded as future sources of hydrogen for CO 2
hydrogenation [3,4] . In addition, fundamental chemical products
like oleﬁns can be produced via a methanol-to-oleﬁn (MTO) pro-
cess [5]and various organic compounds like dimethyl ether
(DME), that is, a potential substitute of diesel oil for its better com-bustion performance [6], can be produced from methanol. The
commercially practiced processes of methanol synthesis from CO
and CO
2are operated at relatively low one-pass conversions and
require separation and/or recycling of unconverted reactants to
attain high conversions. Currently, the commercial methanol
synthesis processes are operated typically at about 50–100 bar
using copper- and zinc-based catalysts [7]. Lowering the reaction
pressure is generally favoured because of the general perception
of increased energy demands at high-pressure operation. However,
a recent report on energetic aspects of CO 2hydrogenation to

The ﬁrst high-pressure methanol synthesis process was com-
mercialized by BASF in 1923, operated at pressure of 250–
350 bar with a mixture of syngas with CO 2as reactants [9]. The
use of high pressure was necessary due to thermodynamics; de-
crease in temperature and increase in reaction pressure should fa-

processes are operated at lower reaction pressures of ca. 50–

tive Cu–Zn-based catalysts [10]. Related to CO 2hydrogenation,
Ipatieff and Monroe reported high-pressure study up to 412 bar
over Cu/Al 2O3catalysts in a ﬁxed bed reactor, which showed
remarkable selectivity to methanol and high conversion of CO 2
[11]. However, in their study, the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV),
indicative of the productivity of the reaction, was very low (ca.
1000 h/C01) to make the process practically viable.
Herein, we report high-pressure (up to 360 bar) CO 2hydrogena-
tion to methanol over co-precipitated Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalysts at
high GHSV (>10,000 h/C01). Under speciﬁc reaction conditions with
conventional methanol synthesis catalysts, we will show that one
can achieve close-to-full one-pass conversion of CO 2to methanol.
Furthermore, DME and hydrocarbons production from methanol
can be directly incorporated or combined with the methanol syn-
thesis process, outlining the high ﬂexibility and versatility of the
reported CO 2hydrogenation process.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials
Copper nitrate hexahydrate ( P98%, Alfa Aesar), zinc nitrate
hexahydrate (98%, Sigma–Aldrich), aluminium nitrate nonahydrate
(P98%, Fluka), potassium hydroxide ( P85%, Sigma–Aldrich), c-
Al2O3(Bimodal, Alfa Aesar) and NH 4-ZSM-5 (SiO 2/Al2O3= 50/1, Alfa
Aesar) were used as received. Deionized water was used for cata-
lyst synthesis. A commercial methanol synthesis catalyst was pur-
chased from Alfa Aesar (Product ID: 45776). Liquid CO 2
(>99.9993%) and 10% Ar in H 2(>99.999% for Ar or H 2, prior to mix-
ing) were purchased from Linde.
2.2. Catalyst synthesis
For the synthesis of Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3, aqueous solutions of copper
nitrate hexahydrate (0.2 M), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.2 M) and
aluminium nitrate nonahydrate (0.2 M) with potassium hydroxide
(0.5 M) were slowly added together, in a round-bottom ﬂask to
precipitate the corresponding hydroxides. During the precipitation,
the round-bottom ﬂask was heated at 80 /C176C under constant stir-
ring, and the pH of the solution with precipitate was maintained
between 9.5 and 10.5. The precipitate was aged for 48 h, ﬁltered
and washed with water until the pH of the washed solution
reached the value of 7.5. Then, the sample was dried at 100 /C176C
overnight, crushed and calcined in air at 400 /C176C for 4 h to yield
Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(I). Following the same synthesis procedure, twomore catalysts, Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(II) and Cu/Al 2O3, were prepared
using different compositions of precursor solutions. H-ZSM-5 was
prepared by calcination of NH 4-ZSM-5 in air at 400 /C176C for 4 h. An-
other Cu/Al 2O3(18/82 wt%) catalyst was prepared by the incipient
wetness impregnation method. The preparation method and cata-
lyst properties are described elsewhere [12]. Prior to charging the
catalysts into reactor, they were pelletized, crushed and sieved a
size of 100–300 lm. Elemental composition, Cu surface area, CuO
crystallite size and BET surface area of the synthesized and com-
mercial catalysts are listed in Table S1 (Supplementary material ).
2.3. Catalytic testing
CO2hydrogenation reaction was performed in the microreac-
tion set-up and tubular reactors (ID: 1.74 mm, OD: 3.17 mm) were
used throughout. Details of the set-up and method of product anal-
ysis are described elsewhere [12]. For methanol synthesis, 170 mg
of Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(I) was used. In the study of very low to high
GHSVs using the commercial catalyst, 1000, 85 or 42.5 mg of the
catalyst was used for the catalytic tests in the range of 425,
10,000–40,000 or 81,000–182,000 h/C01, respectively.
For the synthesis of DME, H-ZSM-5 (150 mg) was mixed with
Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3(II) (170 mg) and charged into one reactor or the
two catalysts were charged separately into two reactors connected
in series.
For hydrocarbon synthesis, H-ZSM-5 (170 mg) was charged into
a reactor connected in series after that containing Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3
(II) for methanol synthesis. The temperature of the secondary reac-tor containing H-ZSM-5 was controlled independently from the
ﬁrst one. For alkane synthesis, the reactor with H-ZSM-5 wasplaced before the back pressure regulator, thus kept at the same
pressure as the ﬁrst one ( Fig. S8 ). While in alkene synthesis, the
secondary reactor was located after the back pressure regulator
(Fig. S9 ) and kept at the atmospheric pressure. It should be noted
that GHSVs for the combined processes (DME and hydrocarbon
syntheses) were calculated based on the amount of the methanol
synthesis catalyst in the reactor.
For the above three reactions, argon was used as an internal
standard for gas chromatography (GC) analysis and product selec-
tivity was calculated taking only carbon-containing products into
account.

ble extent. Under this condition, the methanol weight time yield
(WTY) was found to be 1 :2gMeOH g/C01
cath/C01.
Theoretical equilibrium conversion values for CO 2and H 2at
various CO 2/H2ratios under this reaction condition ( Supplemen-
tary material, Fig. S1 ) show interesting insights of the catalytic per-
formance. It is worth highlighting that the equilibrium conversion
is very high (>94%) even when the mixture is at the stoichiometric
ratio (CO 2/H2= 1:3, Fig. S1 ) under the high-pressure condition.
Experimentally at CO 2/H2= 1:<10, the conversion values are far
from the equilibrium values, while at 1: P10 the values are almost
identical to those expected from the equilibrium ( Fig. 1 vs.S1). The
WTYs were smaller at the high H 2partial pressures due to lower
CO2mass ﬂow at the constant GHSV ( Table S2 ). The results indicate
that at the feed ratio of 1: P10, the process operates in the thermo-
dynamic regime reaching the equilibrium CO 2conversion and
methanol selectivity under the investigated condition, whereas at
the feed ratio of 1:<10, the reaction falls into the kinetic regime.
Judging from the similar theoretical equilibrium conversion at
the different CO 2/H2ratios, the experimentally observed outstand-
ing CO 2conversion and methanol selectivity at high H 2partial
pressure (i.e. CO 2/H2=1 :P10) are most likely due to the rate accel-
eration for methanol formation by the high H 2partial pressure. Be-
sides, the H 2conversion was observed to be decreasing with the
increase in H 2partial pressure, as expected from the excess of H 2
relative to CO 2. However, it should be noted that the energy efﬁ-
ciency towards methanol formation was greatly enhanced at
CO2/H2=1 :P10 because of the suppressed, competitive reverse
water–gas shift (RWGS; CO 2+H 2?CO + H 2O) reaction. The H 2
consumption rate at conventional feed ratio of 1:3 was found to
be 88 mmol g/C01

is an important fact in practice because at high H 2partial pressure
the energy (incl. hydrogen molecules as chemical energy) and time
(thus for better yield) required for methanol production are mini-
mized and solely used for methanol synthesis. Also, we demon-
strated the documented analogies of high-pressure advantages
between methanol synthesis and classic Haber–Bosch ammonia
synthesis processes by achieving the equilibrium yield [13].Fig. 2 depicts the effects of temperature on the catalytic perfor-
mance at 360 bar, CO 2/H2= 1:10, and GHSV of 10,471 h/C01. A rise in
temperature greatly enhanced CO 2conversion, reaching the maxi-
mum at 260 /C176C with the aforementioned outstanding methanol
productivity. Further rise in temperature resulted in methanol
selectivity decrease and in apparent compensating increase in CO
formation. At a lower pressure of 200 bar, a similar trend with a
maximum in the catalytic performance at 280 /C176C was observed
(XCO2= 79%, S MeOH = 88%, Fig. S4 ). This great enhancement in meth-
anol selectivity upon temperature increase is surprising at ﬁrst
glance because the competitive RWGS reaction is an endothermic
reaction and higher temperature should facilitate the reaction with
respect to methanol synthesis that is an exothermic reaction and
preferable at lower temperature [10,14] .
Comparing the obtained results to the thermodynamic calcula-
tions ( Figs. S2 and S3 ), above 260 /C176C the reaction reaches close to
the equilibrium conversion, hence falling into thermodynamic re-
gime. This thermodynamic control can be clearly conﬁrmed by
reproduction of the trend for the unexpected decrease in CO 2con-
version above 260 /C176C, accompanying decrease in methanol selec-
tivity ( Fig. 2 vs.S2 and S3 ). On the other hand, below 260 /C176C the
CO2conversion was far from equilibrium and the enhanced meth-
anol selectivity towards higher temperature up to 260 /C176C can be re-
garded due to the kinetic control. When the reaction is kinetically
controlled, the high selectivity to CO is more pronounced ( Fig. 2 )a s
observed for the aforementioned kinetically controlled regime
(Fig. 1 )a tC O 2/H2= 1:<10. This observation suggests that the CO 2
hydrogenation to methanol proceeds via CO.
It is intriguing to notice that with the Cu/Al 2O3catalyst pre-
pared by the impregnation route, the formation of products was
observed to be in accordance with the thermodynamic principles,
i.e. better methanol selectivity at lower temperatures and higher
CO selectivity and higher CO 2conversion at higher temperatures,
but with overall poor catalytic performance very far from the equi-
librium ( Table S3 ). There may be some differences in the nature of
active sites of the catalysts prepared by the impregnation and co-
precipitation routes. Also, the boosting in catalytic performance
with a maximum at a speciﬁc temperature was not observed with
the Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalyst at the conventional CO 2/H2ratio of 1:3
(Fig. S5 ). The absence of the maximum is likely due to the kinetic
control by the poorer catalytic performance at the lower H 2partial
pressure as evidenced by the higher CO selectivity ( Fig. S5 ).
Ipatieff and Monroe reported that under high-pressure condi-
tions, CO 2is ﬁrst reduced to CO via the RWGS reaction accompany-
ing the formation of water, and subsequently to formaldehyde as a
secondary reaction. The formed formaldehyde was suggested to be
further reduced to methanol via two pathways: one via direct
hydrogenation and the other via Cannizzaro reaction [11].I ti s
widely accepted that methanol is directly formed from CO 2rather
than CO [15–17] ; however, this may be applicable to reactions at
low or moderate pressures. In context with such high pressure
and with obtained high conversions, the pathway for methanol for-
mation via CO, suggested by Ipatieff and Monroe, is indeed in
accordance with our observation. The high selectivity to CO at low-
er temperatures can be explained by the slow secondary reaction
of CO towards the formation of methanol. Likely, this secondary
reaction is accelerated by increasing temperature, particularly at
high pressure, and also the amount of methanol is greatly en-
hanced due to the increased amount of CO produced by the endo-
thermic RWGS reaction.
In addition, the formed water may promote CO hydrogenation
as reported in literature [18]. As mentioned previously without
mechanistic studies or operando observation of active sites and
species, which is out of scope of the current investigation, this
study points that CO 2hydrogenation to methanol proceeds via

CO selectivity at higher GHSVs again suggests the previously dis-

commercial catalyst at the very low GHSV of 425 h/C01, in this case
towards methane formation ( Table S6 ). These results point out that
there is an optimal GHSV for methanol productivity and selectivity
in practice.
Furthermore, with the optimal conditions of CO 2/H2ratio, pres-
sure and space velocity, we examined the performance of the co-
precipitated Cu/Al 2O3catalyst without the Zn component. Good le-

was obtained at 280 /C176C(Fig. S6 ). This observation reveals that the
outstanding catalytic performance is related mainly to the high
pressure, to the feed composition and also to the synthesis method
of the catalyst, thus to the speciﬁc state of Cu in the catalysts pre-
pared by the co-precipitation route [20]. The promoting effect of
Cu–Zn combination is recognized but subtly pronounced underthe high-pressure condition of this work. Moreover, the catalytic
performance of Cu/ZnO/Al

The use of bi-functional catalysts for one-step DME production
from CO 2is widely known [2,21] , and solid acid catalysts such as c-

tion [22]. Stimulated by the results obtained for methanol
synthesis, we evaluated one-step conversion of CO 2into DME via
in situ conversion of methanol using physically mixed pre-pellet-

4. Conclusion
The catalytic system described in this work provides an efﬁcient
and highly productive processing strategy for CO 2conversion at a
single step. The high-pressure approach using a conventional Cu/
ZnO/Al 2O3methanol synthesis catalyst under speciﬁc reaction con-
ditions for CO 2hydrogenation remarkably boosted methanol selec-
tivity and productivity by (i) the high H 2partial pressure to
enhance the reaction rate and (ii) thermodynamically favoured
high CO 2conversion and methanol selectivity at high pressure.
The preliminary experiments with the commercial catalyst showed
extraordinary high methanol productivity at very high GHSVs, pos-
sibly justifying the capital and manufacturing costs of high-pres-
sure processes. Negligible pressure drops under the examined
GHSVs are the advantage of compressive reactants at high pres-
sure. The consumed hydrogen was exclusively utilized for metha-
nol formation at increased hydrogen partial pressure, thereby
increasing the efﬁciency of the process towards methanol synthe-
sis by suppressing chemical and thermal energy consumption for
RWGS reaction. Moreover, the excess of hydrogen remaining instream present under the optimal reaction condition reported in
this work can be fed directly to another identical or multiples of
high-pressure reactors with possible reduction in their sizes, so
that compression of hydrogen may only require at initial stage
whereas methanol productivity would be multiples of connected
reactors. In such conﬁgurations, the recycling of H
2can be mini-
mized or potentially omitted.
One-step transformation of CO 2to DME by the co-presence of
the H-ZSM-5 catalyst showed remarkable ability of this process
without lowering the CO 2conversion level. Also, the methanol-,
water- and H 2-rich stream can be directly fed to the reactor con-
taining the H-ZSM-5 catalyst and good selectivity to alkane or al-
kene was attained, instigating further development of CO 2to
oleﬁns and/or gasoline processes via one-step hydrogenation. The
CO2transformation approach presented in this study may allowthe convenient operation of small scale yet highly productive
plants for CO 2hydrogenation at sites where CO 2is captured and
stored.

1. Introduction
Methanol is one of the most interesting industrial chemicals for the past, for the present, and for the future. Methanol, the simplest of
alcohols, is found in nature in small amounts including interstellar space and nature on earth, where it is produced by anaerobe metabo-
lism. Humans made methanol by pyrolysis or destructive distillation of wood for hundreds and even thousands of years before the last
century where it became an industrial commodity and it is now produced in more than 13 l/year for each person on earth. The installed
production capacity of methanol is around 110 million tons per year (MTY) [1], while the demand for methanol was approximately 80–90
million tons in 2018. The requirement for methanol in 2023 is forecasted to exceed 110 MTY and is expected to outgrow the production
capacity. Today, methanol is manufactured from fossil fuels, but methanol can also be made from renewable energy resources. Methanol
has for that reason been suggested as the base molecule in a methanol economy as opposed to a hydrogen economy [2]and in this way
methanol may support the development of energy solutions with reduced greenhouse gas emissions.
The applications of methanol are very diversiﬁed: It is used to make a large series of chemical products including formaldehyde,
dimethyl ether (DME), methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE), tert-amyl methyl ether (TAME), acetic acid, dimethyl terephthalate, methyl chloride,
and oleﬁns via the methanol to oleﬁns/propene (MTO/MTP) process. These chemicals are subsequently applied to make a wide range of
everyday products including fuel additives, resins, plastics, paints, polyester, and building materials. Methanol is also used as a clean burn-
ing biodegradable fuel for vehicles, mainly for fuel blending, and to make high octane gasoline by the methanol-to-gasoline (MTG) or TIGAS
(Topsoe Improved Gasoline Synthesis) processes. It is proposed as an alternative low sulfur marine fuel with low particulate emissions in
near coastal areas from 2020, when the MARPOL legislation becomes effective. There is currently a strong growth in the demand for metha-nol of approximately 6% per year, mainly driven by an increasing demand for oleﬁns made by MTO/MTP and fuel blending especially in
China.

governments to avoid ﬂaring or/and reduce CO 2emissions. An opportunity for this technology could be mass production of small methanol
plants through modulization and process simpliﬁcations that will bring the price of the decentralized methanol production down, even
though competition with modern large-scale plants beneﬁtting from current low gas prices seems unrealistic without an active taxation
or regulation policy. The trend towards small plants may compel the synthesis to change as high pressures, large recycle streams, and com-
plex feed and product puriﬁcation are expensive unit operations, where cost reductions and process integrations and simpliﬁcations are
needed.
3. Interplay between methanol catalyst and technology
Industrial methanol synthesis catalysts applied today operate at 200–300 /C176C and 50–100 bar total pressure and consist of Cu as the
active metal, Al 2O3and ZnO to disperse Cu nano-particles and ZnO to assist Cu in making methanol (promotor). A series of additional pro-
motors such as Cr, Mg, Ca, Si, and Zr are often applied. This type of catalyst formulation was originally invented by ICI in the 1960s and has
undergone important, but incremental improvements over the last ﬁve decades, and we are so far stuck with the advantages and disad-
vantages of this chemical system.
From an industrial point of view, methanol catalysts should fulﬁll several requirements: The ideal methanol catalyst should have low
pressure drop and only moderate diffusion restrictions by choosing the right pellet size and shape, a high pellet strength to ensure mechan-
ical stability during loading and operation and it should also be possible to produce industrially in hundreds of tons with reasonable cost
and ecological footprint. These requirements are challenges that are mainly addressed by industry today, but new potential catalysts devel-
oped by academia must eventually fulﬁll the above requirements. The perfect methanol catalyst should also have decent activity and selec-
tivity, high thermal stability, and good resistance towards poisons such as sulfur, chlorine, nickel/iron carbonyls, etc. These are all
important scientiﬁc challenges to academia and subjects where new fundamental understanding may impact industrial practice. Activities
of methanol synthesis catalysts and understanding of reaction mechanisms and promotor effects have received the majority of the atten-
tion in the scientiﬁc literature. Selectivity, poisoning, and thermal stability of methanol synthesis catalysts are less discussed even though
there are excellent articles on these subjects [4–10] . Academia could provide more understanding of the mechanisms of poisoning (resis-
tant) processes, catalyst stability, and synthesis of byproducts.
The developments towards large-scale plants, more CO 2rich feeds, waste gas streams, small-scale plants, and variable feed availability,
bring new challenges to the scientiﬁc and industrial communities. One or more of the synthesis gas components in plants making use of
renewable feedstocks like CO 2waste streams and electrolysis are in general supplied at low pressure, and the cost of pressurizing to stan-
dard synthesis pressures of 50–100 bar is high. There is a wish to make methanol at lower pressures than today and thereby reduce both
investment and operational costs, but this will come at a price of lower equilibrium conversions of the synthesis gas in a single pass of the
reactor as depicted in Fig. 2 . One of the strongest desires in the methanol industry is development of methanol synthesis catalysts (and
processes) that are able to operate at conditions where the conversion per pass of the methanol reactor is signiﬁcantly higher or even
to make a once-through methanol synthesis process. It is possible to increase the conversion of one reactor pass by decreasing the tem-
perature, but diminishing reaction rates over the present methanol catalysts at low temperatures now limit the temperatures to approx-
imately /C21200/C176C. Making methanol catalysts more active at low temperatures could be an important improvement especially in small
plants as lower pressures may reduce the price of the compression section considerably. Yet, the progress made so far has been limited.
This is most certainly due to interdependencies of the changes in thermodynamic properties of metals that are best illustrated by the
so-called scaling relations where adsorption energies and reaction barriers scale simultaneously with fundamental descriptors such as oxy-
gen and carbon adsorption energies [11]. Breaking these relations, for example, by using oxides/carbides or nitrides instead of metals is a
major challenge to science, but also a direction to possible improvements in a heavily-explored scientiﬁc ﬁeld.
The dream of nearly full conversion in a single reactor pass may also be obtained by breaking the thermodynamic limitations of the gas
phase equilibrium for making methanol using a condensing methanol reactor. CO xand H 2are converted to condensing methanol in this
type of reactor, thereby eliminating methanol from the gas phase. The process is not commercial yet, although >95% conversion can be
obtained in a single pass, but this approach holds an interesting perspective [12].
Catalysts with higher capacities towards poisons or even catalysts tolerating poisons such as sulfur [10] would be highly interesting.
Such improvements would allow us to mitigate current challenges with poisons, handle new poisons, simplify and reduce cost of
(small-scale) plants, and thus help us making methanol more efﬁciently. Today, typical impurities like sulfur, nickel, and iron are generally
handled in the puriﬁcation section with hydrogenation catalysts and absorbents as well as by avoiding metal dusting and making sure that
the plant is clean before start-up. Nevertheless, the production of many plants is still inﬂuenced by in principle preventable poisoning, so
efﬁcient handling of this issue is still important. Applications of alternative gas feeds with impurities that are not normally encountered in
conventional plants, combined with the demand for simplicity of small plants, makes it desirable to make improvements in this area [13].
The lifetime of methanol catalysts in industry is generally 2–4 years, when impurities are under control, but the activity of the catalysts
drops during this time span even in the absence of catalyst poisons [3,5,6,7,14] . Methanol plants usually counteract catalyst deactivation by
adjustments of the synthesis pressure, recycle ﬂow, and/or synthesis temperature to maintain the productivity of the plant although these
actions result in an increase in energy consumption.
One of the dreams in methanol synthesis is to make a more stable methanol synthesis catalyst and to avoid or reduce thermal deacti-
vation during the industrial lifecycle. Sintering of methanol synthesis catalysts is complicated as it is not just Cu particles, but also ZnO and370 J. of the catalyst [5,6] . Plants for making methanol from CO 2/H2gas mixtures are successfully designed with today’s technology. However,
making CO 2the primary carbon source of methanol increases steam partial pressures in the synthesis and tends to increase catalyst sin-
tering. This is illustrated by the fact that Cu catalysts in general have lower Cu surface areas after exposure to low-temperature water gas
shift conditions as compared with after methanol synthesis. It is therefore desirable to focus on thermal stability of methanol catalysts in
general and especially in CO 2to methanol applications, where the conditions are more challenging than when today ´s more CO rich feeds
are employed. Academia can play an important role in providing understanding and ideas for new and more durable methanol catalysts.
The CO 2conversion to methanol can also be improved by catalysts that only catalyze methanol synthesis and not the reverse water gas
shift reaction (RWGS), the reverse of reaction (3). An additional advantage could be a decrease of the water content of the gas over the
catalyst and thereby possibly reduce water-induced sintering. Fig. 3 illustrates the equilibrium conversions after equilibrating the metha-
nol reaction – with and without equilibrating the water gas shift reaction. An increase in the equilibrium conversion can be obtained at
higher temperatures and may have some applicability in adiabatic reactors, if the low temperature activity of today ´s catalysts is main-
tained, but using standard methanol synthesis temperatures seems more favorable for conversion. To evaluate industrial relevance, future
work should focus on CO formation at high conversions to methanol. It is also important to separate selectivity to CO from those of hydro-
carbons and C 2+ alcohols, because CO may be recycled while formation of higher alcohols, methane, higher hydrocarbons or wax repre-
sents a loss of product and a separation or even a fouling problem.
Decreasing byproduct formation could also result in optimized plant designs for example by increasing temperature in adiabatic and
cooled reactors to increase activity and reduce reactor size and still obey the requirements of low byproducts or reduce the size of the dis-
tillation section. Byproduct formation is presumably controlled by the reaction routes proposed for synthesis of higher alcohols over Cu
catalysts [16].
Finally, it should be mentioned that other paths may be used to make methanol such as electrochemical reduction of CO 2-to-methanol
and direct catalytic and non-catalytic oxidation of methane-to-methanol. The two latter processes are difﬁcult due to high barriers for C AH
activation of methane and higher activity of C AH bonds in methanol [17,18] , and for the former, there are still huge technical challenges
[19]. If we get a breakthrough for these processes, it will be highly interesting, and it will have the potential to transform industry and make
small plants more feasible, but these processes are still far away from being industrially relevant. The focus that follows will therefore be on
perspectives for the current industrial catalyst.
4. Mechanism, carriers and promoters for methanol synthesis catalysts
First, a few comments on the literature on methanol synthesis catalysts will be made. Although methanol synthesis catalysts represent a
relatively mature technology, it is still a dynamic research area with many new emerging directions and with several contradicting views
on fundamental catalytic aspects. It is possible to ﬁnd support for nearly every hypothesis about the reaction mechanism, the active site
and how promoters and carriers affect catalyst activity in the huge literature on these subjects. Thorough challenging scientiﬁc discussions
are very stimulating, but previous results are sometimes not taken appropriately into account in newer reports. It is important that new
mechanisms and concepts are suggested with great care and thoroughness, as the literature will otherwise tend to diverge rather than con-
verge, and subsequent conclusions will be difﬁcult to draw. It is perhaps a tendency that publication of new mechanisms or concepts are
easier and more honorable than evaluating in detail whether the new ﬁndings indeed are substantial contributions leaving thorough test-
ing of new or older hypotheses as clean-up-work that can be overlooked. This means that the literature is growing, but solid coherent pic-
tures do not necessarily emerge.
Care is also important in the particularly interesting subject of new catalysts. It is important that proposed new formulations are tested
at relevant synthesis conditions, where they can be compared directly with industrial type catalysts. Technical details should be sufﬁciently
described to render reproduction and make a thorough evaluation possible. Furthermore, sometimes less active reference catalysts are
used for comparison and it is recommended that new catalysts are compared not only on a turn-over-frequency (TOF) basis, but also
on a weight and volume basis with the current Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3catalyst that has high density and surface area of the active material. This
would make it easier to base new improvements on solid common knowledge in the ﬁeld.
Nevertheless, the literature contains many excellent scientiﬁc reports including studies of catalyst formulations, preparations of Cu/ZnO
catalysts, mechanisms for methanol synthesis over Cu and Cu/ZnO catalysts, and interactions between Cu and ZnO, which will be discussed
brieﬂy below.

5. Cu – Zn interactions
Today, all commercial catalysts contain Cu and ZnO1, which raises the question of whether zinc is unique and the only relevant promoter
for Cu-based methanol catalysts? The role of ZnO in the industrial Cu/ZnO/Al 2O3methanol synthesis catalyst has attracted a lot of attention in
the literature and is a very interesting subject scientiﬁcally, not only in itself, but also due to the analogy with other metal-promoter systems.
There is a strong consensus and overwhelming evidence in the literature that ZnO is an excellent electronic and structural (by increasing Cu
dispersion) promoter for methanol formation over Cu [14,15,35,40,50–56] . Just to highlight a few recent studies, Kurz et al. [55] achieved an
improvement in activity of nearly a factor of three upon addition of zinc to a Cu/Al 2O3catalyst and van den Berg et al. [51] measured an
increase in activity of ﬁve to seven times after zinc addition to Cu/SiO 2or Cu/C catalysts. Nakamura and Fujitani [39,52,57,58] estimate a
six and thirteen times improvement in methanol activity when adding twenty surface mole % of Zn to polycrystalline Cu and Cu(1 1 1) before
methanol synthesis, respectively, while Kattel et al. [40,54] claim a 25 to 90 times higher activity upon deposition of twenty mole % ZnO on Cu
(1 1 1). So there is agreement about a signiﬁcant increase in activity of Cu catalysts after zinc addition. One exception is the work of Waugh and
coworkers [59,60] , who claim that zinc is only a structural promoter based on similar TOFs for a series of catalysts calculated from activity
measurements and Cu surface areas obtained by N 2O-RFC (reactive frontal chromatography) [59]. Although nano-crystalline ZnO helps dis-
persing Cu nanoparticles in commercial catalysts, the use of N 2O-RFC may be sidetracked by oxidation of reduced Zn or oxygen vacancies
in ZnO [61,62] .
While the consensus is strong concerning the existence of the promotional effect of zinc in Cu catalysts, the structure of the active site is
still discussed. The origin of the Cu–ZnO synergy is an architype of metal-promoter structure and is one of the most studied examples of
catalyst synergy. Quite a number of different models for the origin of this Cu–ZnO synergy have been proposed [6,15,20,38,40–42,48,49,52–
54,56–59,63–73] . Scientiﬁc discussions have recently focused on Cu shape changes and consequently exposure of more active Cu facets
[65,68,71] , on Cu-ZnO interface sites, for example, at the edges of ZnO overlayers on Cu surfaces [6,40,54,63,64,67] and on partly reduced
single Zn atoms in the surface of Cu [15,35,42,50,52,53,57] . While these models appear contradictory to each other, they may in principle
coexist as discussed further below and to some extent reﬂect different structural responses of the same dynamic phenomenon [15,72] . The
critical issues are therefore ﬁnding their relative contributions to the methanol synthesis reaction rate, determine whether these effects are
interlinked or collaborate and establish how the improved understanding can be used to develop the catalyst.

6. Conclusions
Methanol is a large-scale bulk chemical that is currently manufactured from common fossil hydrocarbon feedstocks. Methanol synthesis
is one of the possible solutions to the energy challenges that we face in the 21st century as it may be produced from renewable resources
and has an energy density that allows demanding long-distance transport without refueling. Methanol is also an excellent precursor for
making many bulk chemicals including oleﬁns, formaldehyde, acetic acid, methyl chloride, DME, dimethyl terephthalate, etc.
One of the main challenges in lowering the environmental footprint of the methanol industry, using small rural gas supplies, biomass
gasiﬁcation or CO 2waste streams combined with H 2from electrolysis, is the demand for more economic solutions for smaller production
plants. It will be difﬁcult for smaller plants to compete with new world class-methanol-plants fueled by cheap natural gas on an equal basis
so subsidies and regulations will be needed in a transition period. However, in a low CO 2emission society, where ﬂaring is unacceptable,
small-scale methanol production could be attractive. The main route to methanol in a foreseeable future is still thermal via synthesis gas as
methanol production via direct electrolysis, photo-catalysis, non-catalytic synthesis and direct methane-to-methanol synthesis, all need
major technological breakthroughs to be commercially interesting.
Today ´s technology provides an applicable solution for combining CO 2and H 2to make methanol, although the industrial methanol syn-
thesis catalyst is slightly less efﬁcient and shows somewhat faster thermal sintering in CO 2rich feed gasses. Making the industrial metha-
nol catalyst even more stable could be interesting, but a really attractive improvement could be to enhance the low temperature activity of
the methanol synthesis catalyst since lower temperatures would allow better equilibrium conditions, lower synthesis pressures, and
thereby decrease the demand for expensive compression especially in smaller productions. Efﬁcient handling of impurities is also an issue
especially in the light of some unconventional impurities present in alternative feed gasses and in this connection a sulfur tolerant synthe-
sis could be highly interesting. Both increasing the knowledge and ﬁnding simpliﬁed solutions to these challenges is of industrial
importance.
Development and understanding of methanol synthesis catalysts are still very active research areas. We could hope that we in the
future, based on experimental evidence, obtain a theoretical description with predictive power to strengthen our search for catalysts with
higher low temperature activity or resistance towards impurities.

Eastern China lakes ABSTRACT  
Satellite observation can significantly reduce the uncertainties in CO2 emission estimations compared to insuf-
ficient field data. However, big challenges remain in developing remote sensing-based models for mapping 
concentrations of dissolved carbon dioxide (cCO2) in lakes at regional or global scales. We developed a cCO2 
estimation model using Sentinel-3-derived lake environmental variables and near-synchronous field cCO2 data 
from 16 lakes in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze and Huai River (ML_YHR) basins in Eastern China 
(N =248). Stepwise quadratic polynomial regressions of several combinations of chlorophyll- a (Chl-a), water 
temperature (Tw), Secchi disk depth (ZSD), and photosynthetic active radiation (PAR)-related variables were 
tested and validated to select the best approach. The final model showed high performance in calibration and 
validation (R2 >0.72, RMSE <6.35 μmol L�1, MAPE <30.31%). The model sensitivity analysis, based on Monte 
Carlo simulations, showed the model ’s estimated bias as <25% based on uncertainties of all input variables. 
Spatial and temporal dynamics of dissolved CO2 concentrations in 113 lakes (≥10 km2) in the ML_YHR basins 
were mapped from 2016 to 2021 using the Sentinel-3 data. The result showed that CO2 concentrations were low 
in the summer and autumn but high in the winter and spring with dramatic variations (e.g., mean coefficient of 
variation: 52.59%). The annual mean CO2 concentrations of lakes revealed that about 28% of the lakes acted as 
weak atmospheric CO2 sinks (14.96 ±1.13 μmol L�1) while the rest were sources (19.22 ±2.02 μmol L�1), 
compared with a mean concentration of CO2 atmospheric equilibrium (16.29 μmol L�1). CO2 concentrations 
decreased with increasing eutrophication and decreasing lake size (p <0.05). This study advances current 
knowledge about CO2 emissions from emerging meso-eutrophic lakes and shows how satellite remote sensing can 
expand the spatiotemporal coverage of lake CO2.   
1.Introduction 
Lakes play an essential role in the carbon cycle as they emit green -
house gas equivalent to nearly 20% of global fossil fuel CO2 emissions 
(DelSontro et al., 2018 ) despite their small surface area, which is only 
about 3.7% of the global non-glacial land area (Verpoorter et al., 2014 ). 
However, current bottom-up estimates of CO2 emissions from lakes have 
significant uncertainties due to the lack of in situ data. One of the crucial 
reasons for these uncertainties is the large bias of lake type in the global 
lake datasets used in the global emission estimation. Global warming 
and nutrient enrichment due to agriculture and urbanization has increased eutrophication of lakes since the 20th century (Ho et al., 
2019 ). About 63.1% of global lakes larger than 25 km2 are already 
eutrophic, covering about 30.5% of the water surface area (Wang et al., 
2018 ). Eutrophication can largely affect the aquatic carbon cycle by 
promoting atmospheric carbon sequestration as sediment and dissolved 
organic carbon (Pacheco et al., 2014 ). However, only <1% of the 7939 
lakes and reservoirs in the dataset of Raymond et al. (2013) represent 
eutrophic lakes, and most of them are boreal lakes north of the 40◦N 
latitude, resulting in a lack of representativeness of lake types and 
regional distribution, which hinders accurate estimation of global lake 
CO2 emissions.

2The carbon processes in eutrophic lakes are significantly different 
from lakes of other types. The increased inputs of terrestrial carbon 
entering the lake with nutrients increase the lake’s CO2 (Weyhenmeyer 
et al., 2015 ). On the other hand, the algae emerging with increasing 
nutrients promote primary productivity and reduce the lake CO2 
(Pacheco et al., 2014 ). The unclear counterbalance of these two pro-
cesses results in complex carbon cycle roles that create many problems 
for eutrophic lakes (DelSontro et al., 2018 ; Loken et al., 2019 ; Borges 
et al., 2022 ). Specifically, even in tropical lakes reported to be strong 
emitters of CO2 into the atmosphere (Marotta et al., 2009 ), eutrophi -
cation induces high Chl-a, which leads to undersaturated dissolved CO2 
that acts as CO2 sinks (Borges et al., 2022 ). As an eutrophic lake in 
temperate regions, Lake Mendota shows dramatic seasonal CO2 varia -
tions (6.8–184.3 μmol L�1) and significant spatial heterogeneity in the 
autumn mixing period (Loken et al., 2019 ). Furthermore, eutrophication 
can offset or even reverse carbon emissions from an oligotrophic lake 
(Pacheco et al., 2014 ). The size-productivity weighted upscaling esti-
mates of global lakes by DelSontro et al. (2018) were about 50% lower 
than the estimation based on size weighted upscaling alone, which also 
proved the importance of eutrophic lakes in global lake CO2 emission 
estimates. Unfortunately, due to the limitations of labor and material 
resources, it is impossible for field sampling to cover all the lakes within 
the higher frequency than quarterly or annually (Raymond et al., 2013 ; 
Holgerson and Raymond, 2016 ). New large-scale approaches need to be 
developed to fulfill the need to monitor the high spatiotemporal varia -
tions in lakes ’ CO2. 
Satellite remote sensing has accumulated massive continuous 
observation data owing to its broad coverage and high spatiotemporal 
resolution. Based on massive satellite-to-field matchups and high- 
precision satellite products, remote sensing methods have become 
essential for synoptic estimation of oceanic surface dissolved CO2 (Bai 
et al., 2015 ; Chen et al., 2016 ; Chen et al., 2019a ). In principle, the 
oceanic surface dissolved CO2 concentration is mainly controlled by 
thermodynamic processes, biological activities, and physical mixing 
(Takahashi et al., 2002 ; Biswas et al., 2004 ; Takahashi et al., 2009 ). 
These processes can be simulated by satellite-derivable variables such as 
sea surface temperature (SST), sea surface salinity (SSS), Chl-a, and the 
downwelling diffuse attenuation coefficient (Kd) (Bai et al., 2015 ; Chen 
et al., 2016 ; Lohrenz et al., 2018 ). As the sea gets closer to the land, the 
interaction between oceanic CO2-controlling processes and their related 
factors gets stronger, complicating the CO2 estimation model. In open 
oceans, dissolved CO2 is mainly controlled by the thermodynamic pro-
cess, and can be estimated by sea surface temperatures using simple 
linear regression (Boutin et al., 1999 ). In relatively closed bays or coastal 
areas (e.g., the Gulf of Mexico, the Baltic Sea, and the East China Sea) 
where biological and river-sea interactions are enhanced, nonlinear al-
gorithms (e.g., polynomial regression, semi-analytics, machine learning 
algorithms) are required. Variables related to biological processes (Chl- 
a, Kd), physical mixing (SSS) and thermodynamic processes (SST) are 
also necessary inputs used to jointly describe the dynamics of dissolved 
CO2 (Bai et al., 2015 ; Chen et al., 2016 ; Parard et al., 2016 ; Lohrenz 
et al., 2018 ). However, models developed for specific sea areas have 
limitations in regional extrapolation performance. Massive multi- 
regional representative field data and more complicated algorithms (e. 
g., semi-analytical and machine learning algorithms) are needed to 
develop models with general applicability for more sea areas (Chen 
et al., 2017 ; Chen et al., 2019a ). 
Unlike the way it’s handled in the ocean, dissolved CO2 in lakes is 
controlled by endogenous biological effects, thermodynamics, physical 
mixing, and exogenous terrestrial organic and inorganic carbon input 
from rivers (Tranvik et al., 2009 ). In particular, due to the relatively 
small volume of lakes, the exchange of material and energy between 
lakes and terrestrial ecosystems via rivers and lake shorelines is intense, 
profoundly affecting various endogenous biochemical processes in lakes 
(Cole et al., 2007 ; Tranvik et al., 2009 ). In addition to predicting lake 
thermal processes, the water temperature can also indicate photosynthesis intensity together with Chl-a and Kd (Qi et al., 2020 ). 
Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) and coloured dissolved organic matter 
(CDOM) are potential predictors of dissolved CO2, because they are in-
dicators of organic matter mineralization processes or exogenous inputs 
that lead to a CO2 increase (Sobek et al., 2005 ; Raymond et al., 2013 ; 
Klaus et al., 2019 ). However, most lakes lack accurate satellite products 
of the variables discussed in this section. Few studies are currently 
available on the use of satellite products to estimate lake CO2, which has 
severely limited the expansion of long-term remote sensing data 
(Campbell et al., 2022 ). There are only exploratory studies on Lake 
M¨alaren (Kutser et al., 2015 ), Lake Erie (Ouyang et al., 2017 ), and Lake 
Taihu (Qi et al., 2020 ). Among them, a relatively mature study by Qi 
et al. (2020) represents the best model (Taihu model) developed for the 
most well-known eutrophic shallow lake in China - Lake Taihu. This 
study reconstructs nearly 20 years of dissolved CO2 in Lake Taihu, 
thereby proving the potential of satellite remote sensing for long-term 
monitoring of lake CO2 dynamics. However, due to the heterogeneity 
of biogeochemical processes among different types of lakes, it is unclear 
whether the Taihu model can be applied to other lakes worldwide. 
Considerable differences have been found in the optical properties 
between lakes as well as between seasons for the same lake, leading to 
great challenges in developing a uniform algorithm for regional or 
global lakes (Shen et al., 2020 ; Pahlevan et al., 2022 ). For instance, lakes 
in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze and Huai River 
(ML_YHR) basins include several types of lakes, from mesotrophic to 
highly eutrophic (Hu et al., 2022 ). The highly eutrophic lakes with 
frequent cyanobacterial blooms in the ML_YHR basins include Lake 
Taihu in the Yangtze Delta and Lake Chaohu in Hefei (the capital of the 
Anhui Province) (Duan et al., 2015 ; Duan et al., 2017 ). Besides, there are 
also lakes with a lower eutrophication and a high river –lake connectivity 
with large amounts of suspended matter, such as Lake Hongze, Poyang, 
and Dongting (Hou et al., 2017 ; Shen et al., 2020 ). MODIS data has 
about two decades of earth observations; however, many algorithms 
based on MODIS data were developed for monitoring the long-term 
dynamics of a single lake (e.g., Lake Taihu) (Shi et al., 2015a ; Shi 
et al., 2015b ; Huang et al., 2017 ). Mature MODIS-based water quality 
parameters algorithms for inland waters have not been fully developed 
to date (e.g., Chl-a), because MODIS was developed for open ocean 
waters and does not have spectral bands in the red and NIR part of the 
spectrum which is critical for estimating Chl-a in eutrophic waters 
(Gitelson, 1992 ; Cao et al., 2022b ). The Sentinel-3 Ocean and Land 
Colour Instrument (OLCI) performance in retrieving water quality pa-
rameters in lakes has been well demonstrated by different authors (Xue 
et al., 2019 ; Shen et al., 2020 ; Soomets et al., 2020a ; Soomets et al., 
2020b ; Pahlevan et al., 2022 ), since it was developed specifically for 
coastal and inland waters. MODIS is also close to the end of its life, while 
funding for the next Sentinel-3 (C, D and onward) is secured for decades 
to come. Therefore, we chose to use the OLCI sensor for evaluating the 
lake CO2 even though it has shorter time series at present. Existing 
studies have achieved a high-precision inversion of the primary optical 
parameters (e.g., Chl-a and ZSD) for lakes in the ML_YHR basins based on 
the Sentinel-3 OLCI data (Xu et al., 2019 ; Shen et al., 2020 ). Standard 
surface temperatures and photosynthetic active radiation products 
derived from Sentinel-3 data have been released, which meet the basic 
requirements of the Taihu CO2 model proposed by Qi et al. (2020) . 
Moreover, the reconstruction of dissolved cCO2 in eutrophic lakes will 
help fill the gap in the current global lake dataset, which is of great 
significance for reducing uncertainty concerning the global lake CO2 
emission estimation. 
This study was conducted to achieve three objectives: (1) to 
construct a high-precision dissolved CO2 concentration estimation 
model suitable for lakes in the ML_YHR basins based on Sentinel-3 data; 
(2) to evaluate the performance and uncertainty of the model by veri-
fying the results with our independent data and comparing with the 
existing research in the ML_YHR basins; (3) to reconstruct a multi-year 
series of dissolved CO2 concentrations for lakes in the ML_YHR basins T. to December 2021. To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first to 
estimate dissolved CO2 in lakes from space at a regional scale. 
2.Data and methods 
2.1. Study areas 
The middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze and Huai River 
(ML_YHR) basins are located in the eastern plain of China (27.78◦- 
36.10◦N, 111.70◦-121.67◦E, Fig. 1). The ML_YHR basins are in a sub-
tropical monsoon climate region with favorable hydrothermal condi -
tions and abundant water sources to replenish the lakes within it. The 
ML_YHR basins includes 605 natural lakes (excluding reservoirs) larger 
than 1 km2, with a total lake area of 20,762 km2 (Ma et al., 2011 ). Due to 
the fast-growing social and economic development of eastern China in 
the last half century, a large amount of nitrogen-rich sewage was dis-
charged into lakes (Yu et al., 2019 ). This excess nitrogen led to the 
deterioration of aquatic ecosystems and fast eutrophication of ML_YHR 
lakes (Hu et al., 2022 ). The frequent occurrence of cyanobacterial 
blooms endangers the ecological health of lakes and the lives of sur-
rounding residents (Duan et al., 2015 ; Duan et al., 2017 ). At the same 
time, eutrophication dramatically changed the CO2 emission dynamics 
in lakes, making lakes in this region a hotspot for lake-related carbon 
cycle research (Lee et al., 2014 ; Ran et al., 2021 ; Xiao et al., 2022 ). In 
this study, considering the limitations of the spatial resolution 
(approximately 300 m) of the Sentinel-3 OLCI data, 113 lakes (>10 km2) 
located in the ML_YHR basins were examined (Fig. 1). 2.2. Field data 
Based on lake sizes, hydrological conditions, and the trophic status of 
the lakes reported in published studies (Zou et al., 2020 ; Hu et al., 2022 ), 
16 lakes were selected in the ML_YHR basins (as shown in Fig. 1 with 
basic properties shown in Table 1). Six field surveys were conducted in 
July 2018, October 2019, September and October 2020, and April, June, 
and December 2021. For samplings of each lake, 5 to 30 sample points 
were set in the lake’s pelagic area and carried out simultaneously with 
Sentinel-3 overpasses. At each sampling site, surface water samples 
(0–50 cm) were collected to analyses water quality and optical param -
eters (including Chl-a, DOC, CDOM absorbance, and suspended partic -
ulate matter (SPM)). A standard 5 L acrylic water-fetching instrument 
was used to collect the water. The samples were stored in cold dark 
conditions before laboratory analysis. The specific measurement 
methods have been detailed in previous studies (Xue et al., 2017 ; Xiao 
et al., 2020 ). For dissolved cCO2 measurements, a headspace equilib -

the headspace gas were measured using a gas chromatograph (Agilent-

2.3. Satellite data 
Benefitting from the band setting and spatial resolution, the Sentinel- 
3 OLCI is considered one of the most suitable satellite sensors for water 
colour remote sensing in inland waters (IOCCG, 2018 ). Previous study 
has proved the cross-mission consistency of data obtained by OLCI 
sensors equipped on Sentinel-3 A and B (Zibordi et al., 2022 ). Therefore, 
we used the OLCI data that both Sentinel-3 A and B obtained to retrieve 
the lakes ’ optical parameters. Our goal was to obtain the maximum 
number of valid images. The Sentinel-3 A/B OLCI level-1B FR and the 
Sea and Land Surface Temperature Radiometer (SLSTR) level-2 land 
surface temperature (LST) images were downloaded from the European 
Space Agency (ESA) Copernicus Open Access Hub. These images cover 
the ML_YHR basins between May 2016 and December 2021. Image 
quality control and selection were done with the following preprocess -
ing. The Sentinel-3 OLCI level-2 instantaneous PAR (iPAR) product was 
downloaded from the European Organization for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites (EUMETSAT) with online data access at 
https://data.eumetsat.int/ . The MODIS 3 km aerosol product 
(MOD04_3K) was required as an input to the atmospheric correction and 
was downloaded from NASA ’s Earth Observing System Data and Infor-
mation System (EOSDIS, https://earthdata.nasa.gov ). 
Downloaded satellite data were preprocessed following the steps 
shown in Fig. 2. First, the satellite data were roughly subset using the 
lake boundary published by Ma et al. (2011) . Then, the Rayleigh-

derived using the satellite signal in the solar spectrum correction scheme 
(6SV) (Vermote et al., 1997 ). Shen et al. (2020) proved the performance 
of the 6SV processor in large lakes of eastern China, based on compar -
isons with current popular atmospheric correction processors. The spe-
cific options of 6SV processor followed Shen et al. (2020) and are shown

2.4. Model development and selection 
Field data samples and satellite data were matched based on 
geographic coordinates within a time difference of ±3 h. A total of 248 
pairs of matchups were obtained. The distribution of the main param -
eters in the matchups is consistent with the distribution of the total field 
dataset (Fig. S1 g-i), indicating that the matchup dataset is representa -
tive. Accordingly, 60% (N =150) of matchups were divided based on the 
concentration gradient and used as the model calibration set (CAL). The 
remaining 98 matchups were used as the model validation set (VAL). 
Satellite-derived independent variables were used in model develop -
ment in order to cancel uncertainties in satellite products as much as 
possible through regression coefficients. Before model development, 
independent variables with skewed distributions (skewness >2.0 and 
min/max ratio <0.1) were log-transformed to comply with the model ’s 
normality assumption. In our dataset, Chl-a and ZSD needed to be log- 
transformed. In addition, independent variables were standardized to 
suppress the correlation between each other. 
In a previous study, a combination of Chl-a, Tw, Kd, and AccuPAR 
could accurately estimate cCO2 in an eutrophic lake (Qi et al., 2020 ). In 
our dataset, cCO2 was also significantly correlated with ln(Chl- a), Tw, ln 
(ZSD), and AccuPAR (p <0.05), and Kd were highly correlated with ZSD 
(Zhang et al., 2020 ). Thus, a stepwise quadratic polynomial regression 
model was trained using ln(Chl- a), Tw, ln(ZSD), and AccuPAR as inde-
pendent variables (referred to in this research as Model1). 
Considering that AccuPAR may ignore the differences in received 
radiation between samples observed at different times in one field sur-
vey, time-related variables were added to improve model performance. 
The Akaike information criterion (AIC) was used to compare the good-
ness of fit between candidate models. The degree of interpretation of 
cCO2 variations by each model was compared by the coefficient of 
determination (R2). First, AccuPAR was replaced by instantaneous PAR 
variables (iPAR and aPAR). But the model performance did not improve (Table S1). Then we tested other combinations of these PAR-related 
variables. Only the combination of AccuPAR and iPAR improved AIC 
and R2 (Table S1). The corresponding quadratic polynomial model ob-
tained after stepwise regression was referred to as Model2. Based on 
Model2, other time-related variables (Ts, Drs, ks) were added to 
strengthen the estimation ability of samples observed at different times 
for a variety of targeted lakes. Since the AIC and R2 of models were all 
improved after adding these variables (Table S1), these three models 
remained as candidate models, referred to as Model3, Model 4, and 
Model5. Model3 (Drs) emphasizes the time to receive solar radiation. 
Model4 (Ts) emphasizes the absolute moment of observation. Model5 
(ks) focuses on characterizing the amount of radiation accumulated at 
the moment of observation. Furthermore, the candidate models were 
evaluated by the estimation accuracy of the calibration and validation 
sets. The final cCO2 estimation model was decided based on compre -
hensive comparisons of the model ’s goodness of fit, degree of interpre -
tation, and model performance. All models were constructed using the R 
v.4.0.5 (R is a language, and it is used in an environment for statistical 
computing, provided by the R Foundation for Statistical Computing, 
Vienna, Austria; URL https://www.R-project.org/ ). 
2.5. Model sensitivity analysis 
Monte Carlo simulation was used to evaluate the model ’s sensitivity 
to input variables ’ uncertainties. Uncertainties in each satellite-derived 
input variable were quantified based on the mean absolute relative error 
(MAPE ). The max MAPE of Chl-a was 36.91% in (Shen et al., 2022 ). The 
max MAPE of ZSD was 33.43% in (Shen et al., 2020 ). The MAPE of the Tw 
product was 5.20% (Fig. S3 d). The max MAPE of the PAR product was 
9.04% (Fig. S3 b, c). Considering these MAPE from published literature 
or the evaluation results of our dataset, conservative larger uncertainties 
of 40%, 10%, 40%, and 20% were defined for the satellite derived Chl-a, 
Tw, ZSD, and iPAR data, respectively. For each combination of input 
uncertainties, the Monte Carlo simulation ran 100,000 iterations for 
every 248 field-satellite matchups. For simulated variables <0 after the 
error was assigned, the simulations were reassigned to ensure the 
calculation of the model (Chl-a, 1; Tw, 1; ZSD, 0.01; iPAR, 100). Since 
AccuPAR was obtained by integrating the daily iPAR, we did not 
simulate its uncertainty separately but directly transferred the iPAR 
errors to it. The averaged results ranged from 5th to 95th based on 
100,000 simulation results used as the final simulation result to reduce 
the effect of extreme outliers on the simulation results. Statistics on the 
differences between the simulation results and original model outputs of 
all matchups were used to quantitatively evaluate the model ’s sensi-
tivity to the uncertainties of different input variables.
